title: How to Group
text: Grouping requires factoring the first two terms and then factoring the last two terms.
speech: Grouping requires factoring the first two terms and then factoring the last two terms.
pacedSpeech: Grouping requires factoring the first two terms and then factoring the last two terms.

title: Factoring the First Two Terms
text: What is the factored form of $$x^3+x^2$$?
speech: What is the factored form of , x cubed plus x squared ?
pacedSpeech: What is the factored form of  , x cubed plus x squared

title: Factoring the Last Two Terms
text: What is the factored form of $$-9x-9$$?
speech: What is the factored form of  minus 9 x minus 9 ?
pacedSpeech: What is the factored form of   minus 9 x minus 9

title: Common Factor of First and Second Groups
text: Are the factors in the parenthese identical?
speech: Are the factors in the parenthese identical?
pacedSpeech: Are the factors in the parenthese identical?

title: Last Step
text: If the factors in the parenthesis of the first and second groups are identical, the polynomial can be factored by grouping. For example, $$a\left(c+d\right)+b\left(c+d\right)=\left(a+b\right) \left(c+d\right)$$.
speech: If the factors in the parenthesis of the first and second groups are identical, the polynomial can be factored by grouping. For example,  a, parentheses c plus d,  plus, b, parentheses c plus d,  is equal to parentheses a plus b,  times, parentheses c plus d,  .
pacedSpeech: If the factors in the parenthesis of the first and second groups are identical, the polynomial can be factored by grouping. For example,   a,  c plus d,  plus, b,  c plus d,  is equal to  a plus b,  times,  c plus d,
